NATIONAL NEWS






Not plugged into feds' probe: LIPA was unaware that Justice Dept. is questioning KeySpan in investigation of NYC electricity market



Jun. 8--KeySpan Corp.'s revelation this week that the U.S. Department of Justice is seeking information about its role in New York City's troubled electric-energy market did not sit well with the Long Island Power Authority, which had voted just a few hours earlier to approve KeySpan's takeover by London-based National Grid Plc.  The department issued a "civil investigative demand" to KeySpan on ...


Jun 8, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



BGE trade with parent under scrutiny: PSC pledges close look at how relationship affects supply, price



Jun. 8--As a public utility, Baltimore Gas and Electric Co. is obligated to get the lowest price possible for customers. By contrast, its corporate owner, Constellation Energy Group, has a duty to stockholders to sell the power it produces for as much as it can get.  This disconnect is highlighted by the fact that Constellation , which assumed ownership of BGE's former power plants when Maryland ...


Jun 8, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Texas, N.J. firms plan coal power plant in Midland: Facility might be open in 6 years, create 100 jobs



Jun. 8--Two out-of-state energy companies want to spend an estimated $1.5 billion to build a high-tech coal-fired power plant in Midland.  LS Power Group of New Jersey and Houston-based Dynegy Inc. have formed a joint venture called Mid-Michigan Energy that would construct a 750-megawatt plant. The proposed project likely would result in 100 permanent skilled jobs with about 600 to 1,200 ...


Jun 8, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



TXU ENERGY ANNOUNCES CUSTOMER PROTECTIONS



Jun. 8--TXU Energy said Wednesday that it has instituted new electricity service options for low-income customers and seniors. They are aimed at easing financial strains caused by high summer bills.  North Texas' largest electricity provider: Will not disconnect for nonpayment those customers who are either low-income or at least age 62 who sign up for a deferred-payment plan.


Jun 8, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Coal-fired power plant to go up in Midland



Jun. 7--A pair of out-of-state companies plan to spend $1.3 billion to build a coal-fired power plant in Midland, according to a report in the Midland Daily News.  New Jersey-based LS Power and Houston-based Dynegy have formed a joint venture called Mid-Michigan Energy that would construct a 750-megawatt plant. The project is expected to take about six years to complete, including two for ...


Jun 7, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Legislators looking at alternative fuels plant incentives: Senate presidents want special session, but Democrats hesitant



Jun. 8--A proposal designed to lure an alternative fuels plant to Kentucky will be pitched to members of a legislative energy subcommittee during its meeting next week at the TVA Paradise power plant in Muhlenberg County.  The meeting is one of three planned during the next two weeks as Gov. Ernie Fletcher and Senate President David Williams push for a special session of the legislature they say ...


Jun 8, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



TXU eases rules on deposits, cutoffs



Jun. 8--TXU Corp. on Thursday eased its rules for charging deposits to new customers and shutting off electricity for nonpayment during the summer.  The company's retail unit, TXU Energy, won't charge a deposit to new customers who have paid their bills on time for 12 months and will extend the deal to customers who have one late payment during the year. That puts TXU in a more competitive ...


Jun 8, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Talks over proposed coal-fired power plant south of D-FW rile Dallas mayor



Jun. 8--Central Texas leaders are quietly working on a deal that could pave the way for TXU Corp. to build a controversial power plant south of Dallas-Fort Worth in exchange for the energy company agreeing to spend $30 million to make the coal-fired plant cleaner than proposed.  The possible deal comes days before the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality is scheduled to decide whether to ...

Plant in Wharton powers up: Colorado Bend Energy Center starts generating electricity



Jun. 8--WHARTON -- There is now more electricity available to power both economic development and keep home air-conditioners running in Texas this summer. Colorado Bend Energy Center, a new gas-fired combined cycle power plant near Wharton, started generating electricity this month with the completion of the first of two phases.  Once completed, the plant will have the capacity to generate ...

Negotiations under way to sell biogas to Finland



Jun. 8--ZARQA -- The Jordan Biogas Company in Ruseifa is currently conducting negotiations with the government of Finland to sell biogas generated from the Ruseifa landfill, the company's director, Hatem Ababneh, said on Thursday. "Selling the biogas to Finland is an outcome of Jordan signing the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change in 1992 and the Kyoto Protocol, which allow industrialised ...

Olver, Dems denounce renewable energy plan



Jun. 8--WASHINGTON -- Massachusetts Democrats are criticizing aspects of their party's effort to develop renewable energy sources, saying the legislation would undercut Northeastern states trying limit tailpipe emissions -- a move aimed at combating global warming.  They warn that Massachusetts and 11 other states working to curb auto emissions would be blocked by a provision in an energy bill ...

O'Malley adds $5 million to energy-aid program: 3,000 more families to get help in paying higher bills for electricity



Jun. 8--An extra 3,000 families will be able to get help from the state to cope with steeply rising electric rates this summer, Gov. Martin O'Malley said yesterday as he announced $5 million in additional funding for the Electric Universal Service Program.  O'Malley, who has been under fire from critics for his inability to stop the 50 percent Baltimore Gas and Electric Co.


Jun 8, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Wind leaves damage and power outages



Jun. 8--Toppled trees and snapped branches littered Boulder County on Thursday, businesses remained dark well into the day and crews scaled ladders to restore damaged power lines after unseasonably strong winds blew across the Front Range overnight.  Wind gusts Thursday morning hit a high of 92 mph near Rocky Flats, along Colo. 93, said Matt Kelsch, a Boulder meteorologist.


Jun 8, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Winds wreak havoc around Weld



Jun. 8--High winds caused a power outage in Windsor, felled several trees and caused general problems in Greeley and Weld County Thursday.  About 400 Xcel customers lost power for about two hours in Windsor Thursday afternoon, including several downtown businesses on the north side of Main Street. Other sporadic power outages were reported around the state, and there were several reports of tree ...

OG&E announces customer savings



Jun. 8--OG&E Electric Services customers saved more than $177 million over three years since the Oklahoma City company integrated the McClain Generating Plant into its system, OG&E said Thursday.  That's significantly more than the $75 million in savings the company guaranteed that customers would save from 2004-2006. The cost savings won't result in a cut in the rates OG&E charges, because the ...

Feds investigating KeySpan



KeySpan Corp.'s revelation this week that the U.S. Department of Justice is seeking information about its role in New York City's troubled electric-energy market did not sit well with the Long Island Power Authority, which had voted just a few hours earlier to approve KeySpan's takeover by National Grid. The DOJ issued a 'Civil Investigative Demand' to KeySpan on May 31, but the company didn't ...

Wind work winds up



Wind work winds up Xcel restores power cut by 100-mph no injuries reported STORY TOOLS   MORE STORIES By Hector Gutierrez, Rocky Mountain News June 8, 2007 Xcel Energy had restored service to all but about 4,000 customers late Thursday after winds exceeding 100 mph toppled trees and knocked out power to 45,000 Colorado homes. Boulder, where winds reached 92 mph at 1:20 a.m.


Jun 8, 2007 Rocky Mountain News



Questar's earns ire for bid to limit customers' participation in regulation



A Public Service Commission meeting packed with utility customers Wednesday drew the usual complaints about high rates and a regulatory deck stacked in favor of energy companies. But among the three dozen customers who showed up were those worried state regulators would adopt a Questar Gas suggestion to restrict individual Utahns from fully participating in rate cases.


Jun 8, 2007 Salt Lake Tribune



Brief storm knocks out power to 20,000



A brief but intense thunderstorm rolled over Metro Detroit this afternoon, downing limbs and wires from Westland to the Grosse Pointes. Electricity was knocked out for about 20,000 DTE customers scattered through southeastern Michigan. Detroit Edison spokesman Scott Simons said power should be restored to almost all by nightfall. The National Weather Service had issued a severe thunderstorm ...

Wal-Mart Now Canada's Biggest Commercial Buyer of Green Power



JUNE 08, 2007 -- MISSISSAUGA, Ont. -- Wal-Mart Canada Corp.'s three-year agreement to buy 31,000 megawatt hours of clean, renewable power from Bullfrog Power to green the electricity of three of its Alberta stores, together with continuing alternative-energy contracts in Ontario and British Columbia, makes the company the nation's largest commercial purchaser of green power.

LIPA board OKs KeySpan-Grid pact



Over the objections of two county legislators, the Long Island Power Authority board of trustees Wednesday approved a contract for National Grid Plc and KeySpan Corp. to manage the regional power grid, providing a crucial endorsement as the companies seek a state nod to complete their merger. In a unanimous vote after a year of negotiations and a month of deliberations, the board approved the ...

PSE&G Endorses New Transmission Lines To Improve Long-term Electric Reliability in New Jersey



500-kilovolt reinforcements will ease future transmission reliability concerns NEWARK, N.J., June 8 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&G) today endorsed construction of several new 500-kilovolt transmission lines that will significantly improve the long-term reliability of the electric system that serves New Jersey customers.

Fitch Rates PEPCO Holdings' Sr. Notes Issuance 'BBB'; Outlook Stable



NEW YORK--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Fitch Ratings has assigned a rating of 'BBB' to Pepco Holdings, Inc.'s (PHI) (NYSE: POM) $250 million issuance of 6.125% unsecured senior notes due June 1, 2017. The Rating Outlook is Stable. The new notes will rank equally with other senior notes of PHI. Fitch expects that PHI will use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, including to redeem at maturity ...

Progress Energy Carolinas Seeks Slight Fuel Factor Increase in North Carolina



Filing reflects settlement agreement from 2006; average residential impact is 1.3% RALEIGH, N.C., June 8 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Progress Energy Carolinas today filed a request for a slight increase in the fuel rate charged to its North Carolina customers. The increase reflects a settlement agreement from 2006, which spread prior fuel costs over a longer recovery period to minimize the effect ...


Jun 8, 2007 PR Newswire



EC Power Experiencing Strong Growth



HOUSTON--(BUSINESS WIRE)--EC Power, the leading transaction service provider (TSP) in the Electric & Gas Industry, reported today several significant milestones thus far in 2007. The strong growth for the Texas-based company follows an impressive year of growth in 2006, when EC Power greatly broadened their customer base by adding 7 new customers and grew revenue by 14%.


Jun 8, 2007 Business Wire



EPRI Analysis Finds California Can Meet Greenhouse Gas Reduction Goals, But Economic Costs Depend on Approach



PALO ALTO, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--The Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) today released the results of an analysis that shows that California can achieve its goals of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2020, but at a cost to the states economy. Depending on how California implements its climate legislation, cumulative real costs to the states economy range from 0.2 ...

OG&E's McClain Savings Exceed $177 million



Company's rates improve to 24 percent below national average OKLAHOMA CITY, June 7 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- OG&E Electric Services customers have saved more than $177 million since the company integrated the McClain Generating Plant into its system. The savings, reported Thursday in a filing with the Oklahoma Corporation Commission, are significantly greater than the $75 million the company ...

Everton Energy Selects R.J. O'Brien for Risk Management Services



WICHITA, Kan.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Everton Energy, LLC announced today that it has selected R.J. OBrien and Associates, Inc. (RJO), as a strategic partner in implementing its risk management program. Everton Energy is in the business of developing and acquiring renewable energy production and is initially focused on ethanol plants. RJO is the nations largest independent futures brokerage firm.

U.S. Wind Industry Milestone: GE Ships 1,000th 1.5-Megawatt Wind Turbine For FPL Energy



Los Angeles, CA - Two leaders of the U.S. wind industry, GE Energy and FPL Energy, recently announced a milestone for their wind businesses: the shipment of the 1,000th GE 1.5-megawatt wind turbine for an FPL Energy project. The landmark unit will be among the 267 machines GE is supplying for FPL Energy's Peetz Table Wind Energy Center in Colorado. By year-end 2007 the number of GE wind turbines ...

US FERC approves reduced conditional ComEd transmission rate hike



The US Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has approved conditionally an increase in Commonwealth Edison's transmission rates, Exelon, the Chicago-based utility's parent company, said Friday. In a US Securities and Exchange Commission filing Friday, Exelon said FERC on Tuesday approved a formula-based transmission rate that would see the average bill of a ComEd residential customer rise by about ...

TXU Energy Adopts New Measures Designed to Protect Customers



- 5:52 p.m. DALLAS (AP) - TXU Energy, the electricity generation unit of TXU Corp., said Thursday it has initiated new customer protections including a summer moratorium on disconnects for critical care, low-income and older customers. TXU said it will also waive deposit requirements for low-income residential customers that are at least 62 years old, and for all customers with a good record of ...

Yingli Green Energy Announces Pricing of Initial Public Offering of its American Depositary Shares



BAODING, China--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Yingli Green Energy Holding Company Ltd. (NYSE: YGE), a leading vertically integrated manufacturers of photovoltaic, or PV, products in China, announced the pricing of its initial public offering of American Depositary Shares (ADSs) at a price to the public of US$11.00 per ADS. Each ADS represents one ordinary share of Yingli Green Energy.

BOULDER CITY, Nevada--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Acciona Solar Power, a world leader in the design, development and ownership of solar thermal technologies, has announced that its Nevada Solar One project, the largest-capacity solar power plant built in the world in 16 years and the third-largest of its kind, has begun supplying power to the Nevada Power grid. Enel wins auction for 25 per cent of Russia's power generator OGK-5



7 June 2007 - Italy's Enel has won an auction for a 25 per cent stake in wholesale power generating company OGK-5 from electricity monopoly UES, offering 39.2bn roubles ($1.52bn) for the shares. The other bidders were E.On Russia Power, aluminium giant RUSAL and natural gas producer Novatek. The initial bidding price was set at 24.6bn roubles. OGK-5 is one of the six wholesale power generating ...

USW, GAMESA Announce Ratification of First Contract



03:27 PM Eastern Daylight Time USW, GAMESA Announce Ratification of First Contract PHILADELPHIA--(BUSINESS WIRE)--New USW members at Gamesa in Ebensburg, PA and Fairless Hills, PA have voted to approve their first contract by an 80% vote in favor.
